content: The electric utility industry is a major source of air pollution, including sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, mercury, and carbon dioxide. The EPA released an analysis comparing different approaches to controlling this pollution, including market-oriented mechanisms. The Administration's "Clear Skies" proposal was compared to bills by Senators Jeffords and Carper, with the Administration initially reluctant to conduct the study due to cost and difficulty. The Administration has conducted a cost-benefit analysis of the "Clear Skies" proposal and bills introduced by Senators Jeffords and Carper, after initially being reluctant to do so. This analysis was prompted by the failure of the Clear Skies bill to advance in Congress due to concerns about the lack of comparison with other bills. EPA Administrator Stephen Johnson promised to conduct the analysis, which has now been released. Electric utility generating facilities are a major source of air pollution, emitting gases like particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and mercury. These pollutants pose risks to human health and welfare. EPA has finalized rules to regulate mercury, and carbon dioxide may also pose indirect risks. Electric utility generating facilities emit gases like particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and mercury, which pose risks to human health. In 2003, fossil-fuel-fired electric generating plants in the US accounted for a significant portion of SO2, NOx, and CO2 emissions.
